data.name: Adding Functions To The String Prototype
data.description:
# Adding Functions To The String Prototype --- ## 1. Introduction

Which JavaScript developer hasn't asked him/her - self why there are no methods to iterate over Strings exactly like you can do with arrays ?!? All the 'splitting' and 'joining' to manipulate Strings, is just producing...

- Pissed programmers - Wasted time - Unneccessary clutter - Reduced code readability ## 2. Plan

Soo, why don't we just implement our own String iteration functions ?
Some higher-level functions you also know from the Array prototype implementation, will already be of enormouse help...

#### 2.1 Extend Prototype With - [ ] **map**    **⇾** Applies function argument to every char and returns an array - [ ] **filter** **⇾** Keeps chars which fullfill the conditions of the function argument and returns a new string - [ ] **reduce** **⇾** Takes function that reduces array from . . . - [ ] **left**  **⇾** Starts at the beginning(here: left) and moves to the end so, left ⇾ right - [ ] **right** **⇾** Starts at the end(here: right) and moves to the beginning so, right ⇾ left ## 3. Goal - Add the functions specified in 2.1 to the String.prototype - Set the prototype functions as non-enumerable - Add logic to control wether the 'reduce' function should iterate from left -> right or vice-versa (use 0 for left, 1 for right as arguments) - Pass all tests ## 4. Hint #### 4.1 Use ADT's As A Means Of Case-Based Flow Control

Algebraic data types are not the same as algebraic structures. What are they? They’re composite data types made out of othertypes. There’s  two main kinds of algebraic data types: Sum types and Product types. Together, they’re like a dynamic duo for encoding business logic.They help us make good things possible, and badthings impossible.

## 5. Outroduction

My neurons start firing slowly but surely, and the task becomes vivid . . . . . . something like a flow-control . . . hmm . . .
. . . that could be of use in . . . hmmn . . .
. . . somewhere . . .
. . . I forgot . . . hmm . . .


**I'm sure you will figure it out ;)**
